articles.title: About this site
articles.contents:
About Me
My name is Suvan Dommeti and Im an incoming Freshman
at The Ohio State University
About the Project
My project, Presence of Polarzing Words in Australian Media,
explores the presence of a pair of words(“protest” and “riot”). Many
times in media these words are interchanged to achieve a certain
message. I wanted to see whether there was a clear excessive use of
either word in recent years by Australian media
Goals
To determine if either word was excessively used Graph the
presence of each word over years and also specifically in 2021

articles.title: Presence of Polarzing Words in Australian Media
articles.contents:
Introduction
In this project I hope to investigate the presence of the word
“protest” and “riot” in Australian media. After searching the web I
found an data source containing article headline, content and publish
date from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or ABC.
Importance
Its important to see if a news source is disproportionately using
words like riot in their publications because its an indicator that
their publications have some sort of bias. The goal of this project is
to develop a method of identifying the number of times a keyword is
present as well as displaying it.
Table
First lets take a look at some of the headlines in Australian News.
Its always smart to take a quick glance at your data before you use it
incase there are any glaring problems. Lets also add columns to tell us
if the word Riot or Protest is present within the headline




Ok now that we took a look at our data, lets start graphing. To graph
Categorical Data we need to first quantify our variables. To do this
lets count the number of occurrences of “True” within each column. Once
we have a number we can group by year.
Now lets graph!
Presence of riot
and protest from 2003 to 2021



Conclusion
We can see there is no clear trend in this graph. This allows us to
assume that there has been no excessive use of either word by ABC.
Presence of riot and
protest in 2021



Conclusion
Even as we analyze the specific year we can see that there is no
trend. Although this is not definitive proof that this source is
reliable, it gives the reader a little more trust.
Source
My Source of Data was from ABC-Australia *the link to download the
data can be found at <https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/therohk/million-headlines>
